# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    filtered_df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    add_column!(filtered_df, :audi_a4_type => true)
    return filtered_df
end
```

### Execution Results

```plaintext
Execution has been successful (no errors detected). Consider adding 1-2 challenging unit tests to improve the main function - use `@test` macro, organize them in `@testset begin .. end` block.
```

Take a deep break. Think step-by-step and fix the above errors. I believe in you. You can do it! I also need code, actual working Julia code, no shortcuts.

```julia
using DataFrames

struct AudiFilter
    df::DataFrame
end

function (af::AudiFilter)(filtered_df)
    manufacturer = af.df[:manufacturer]
    model = af.df[:model]
    
    audi_rows = findall(x -> x == "audi", manufacturer)
    a4_or_a4_quattro_rows = filter(row -> row == "a4" || row == "a4 quattro", model[audi_rows])
    filtered_df = DataFrame(manufacturer=af.df.manufacturer[audi_rows], model=af.df.model[audi_rows], audi_a4_type=true)
    
    for i in a4_or_a4_quattro_rows
        push!(filtered_df, :manufacturer=>af.df.manufacturer[i], :model=>af.df.model[i], audi_a4_type=true)
    end
    
    return filtered_df
end
```
